title: Should playing ranked and ending the match with less than 1.0:0 KDA be considered intent feeding?
body:
Yes or No

Why?

**Should it also be bannable?**

Yes or No?

Why?


**EDIT:**
Kill neutral is fine. Its rare but its fine.



**How KDA is calculated, Kills + Assists Divided by Deaths**

**EG:
1 kill + 1 Assist Divided by 2 Deaths = 1.1 KDA**

replies.body:
Your example is wrong -  1 Kills plus 1 Assist divided by 2 deaths is - (1+1)/2 = 1:1 so a neutral KDA

But no I don't think it should be classified as intent feeding, sometimes the opponent or opposing team is just better. 
If it's a constant pattern in your game play (then maybe), but, chances are you're going to lose a lot and you'll move down ranks.

Bannable again no, too harsh a punishment if for the player on tilt, or a new to ranked that got lucky in provisions and placed higher than there skill etc.
But I wouldn't be against a scaling system of LP loss for a -ve KDA, the more negative the more severe the LP drop, moves players down quicker if they're in the wrong spot, and would discourage people playing ranked on tilt, due to losing there rank.

But in counter to that it would only be fair for the player that's solo carrying and getting super +ve KDA's to gain extra LP and push him/herself to the rank they suit quicker. (Though these players are most likely smurfs)

Picture a top lane nasus that is 0/0/0 with 200+ farm and enemy team ff at 20

No, That's kill Neutral!

Which is fine.

picture a fountain lane karthus then, who goes 3/0/14 who picked midlane but never left the fountain. KDA means very little in the greater scheme of things. If I'm playing support and the toplane teemo is getting 5 man camped and is still managing to hold his towers somehow with shrooms despite dying repeatedly whilst we're securing inhibitors and dragons; I still consider him mvp for keeping 5 people up there and basically winning us the game.
 Also what about when buffing and cc supports put themselves on the line to hard carry compared to when they stand back and just buff from a distance enough to get the assist. When the soraka does most damage on the team and puts out silences and slows during teamfights compared to when she sits back and just heals occasionally. When that janna helps makes picks and throws herself into a teamfight to perform the winning typhoon ult. What about that splitpush jax who went 1-6-2 but solo took 8 towers, 3 inhibs and a dragon. He might not have gotten kills but the gold and map pressure he earned was well worth it.

Considering game performance purely by kda is a very bronze thing to do.

I'm not saying feeding is fine, but there is a much bigger strong than kda and sometimes as a support main I get annoyed with people in ranked who are so obsessed with kda, chasing kills over immediate objectives, and are aiming for a perfect kda rather than winning.

There's a lot more to it than KDA. Consider, if you will, tanks (as an example). Their main jobs are to engage the enemy team, soak up damage and peel for allies. This, of course, means they typically end up with more deaths than their allies, sometimes with little or no kills/assists. Should these people be punished for doing what is expected of their role? Of course not.

That said, such an idea could be used to help identify intentional feeders. I think we could all agree that any player who consistently gets a KDA ratio of less than 1:4 (less than 1 kill/assist for every 4 deaths) would likely be someone who is intentionally feeding. It should not be that hard for Riot to implement a system that identifies these players and flags them for further investigation.
